title: Sophie Turner attacks influencers who promote diet products
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Sophie Turner has become the latest star to speak out about against influencers promoting diet products and TBH, we’re glad to hear it.

The 23-year-old actress, who has spoken in the past about her struggle with eating disorders, took to Instagram Stories where she pretended to be an influencer selling dodgy diet products.

Using a filter that made her lips look filler-licious and speaking with a very convincing American accent, Sophie began: ‘Hey you guys, just kind of going for my influencer look today.’

‘Today I just wanted to promote this new powdered stuff that you put in your tea and basically it makes you s*** your brains out and is totally really really bad for me to be promoting to young people and young women everywhere,’ the Game of Thrones star continued.

‘But I don’t really give a f*** because I’m getting paid money for it.’

Ending the video with the words: ‘Influencer life,’ it seems like Sophie is clearly on Team Jameela Jamil, supporting her fellow British actress in her tirade against the immoral advertising practice.

Sophie clapped back (Picture: Sophie Turner/Instagram)

Jameela, who stars in The Good Place, has been a vocal campaigner against the promotion of fitness teas, milkshakes and sweets on Instagram (many of which have laxative properties), arguing that influencers such as the Kardashians promote these unsafe products despite not using them themselves.

‘Essentially, “f*** the young, impressionable people, or those struggling with eating disorders, we want the money,’ Jameela previously said.

Jameela vocally opposes the influencer trend (Picture: Michael Tran/FilmMagic)

‘I have been given these same opportunities to flog this stuff, and I don’t do it, so they don’t have to. Thank you, next.’

In September, Instagram finally took a step in the right direction by restricting the promotion of diet products to under 18s and outright banning any product that ‘makes a miraculous claim about certain diet or weight loss products, and is linked to a commercial offer such as a discount code.’ Yes!

Speaking about the change, Jameela said: ‘Facebook and Instagram taking a stand to protect the physical and mental health of people online sends an important message out to the world.

‘I’m thrilled to have been able to work towards this with them, alongside a host of other experts who shed light on the danger of these products.’
